Speaker: howard
Dialogue: We gonna need food. Wait here.

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: Come on!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Where you goin?

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: We gotta go!

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: Bye, Denver. You take care.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Bye? Bul?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No..Bul...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Now what you go and do that for?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Ya know what I'd love to see? I loved to see me some lavender. You got any lavender? Or even pink - pink'll do.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No. Sorry.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Ah, winter in Ohio is especially rough if you've got an appetite for color.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Oh, that's fine. Fine.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: They'll be all right. I'm surprised they lasted here this long.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe we should have moved.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: What'd be the point? Not a house in the country ain't packed to the rafters with some dead Negro's grief. We lucky our ghost is a baby. My husband spirit come back? Or yours? Don't talk to me! Ha..You lucky. You got one child left, still pullin at your skirts. Be thankful. I had eight. Eight with six fathers. Every one of them gone from me. Four taken, four chased and all, I expect, worrying somebody's house into evil. My first born - alls I can remember of her now is how she loved the burned bottom of bread. Her little hands..I wouldn't know'em if they slapped me. Can you beat that? Eight children and that's all I remember.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You remember Halle.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Oh, I remember bits and pieces of all of'em I guess..Halle, of course..I had Halle a lifetime. Almost twenty years... My two girls, sold and gone before I could even a heard about it, and them without their grown up teeth yet. My third child, my son after Halle...I let that straw boss have me for four months so's I could keep that boy. Next year, he had him traded for lumber anyway and me pregnant with his child. I couldn't love that child. I wouldn't. Not any of the rest either. God take what He would....and He did...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: The boys wouldn't have left if Halle were here.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Those boys didn't even know him. You had six whole years of marriage to my Halle Fathered every one of your children. A blessing. I learned hard that a man's just a man, but a son like that...like Halle..now that's somebody.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Just got a few more things to do, then I'll start supper.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Mama?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What is it baby?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You think maybe when daddy comes, he could talk to the baby ghost. Maybe make her behave and then people won't be scared of here no more.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Why won't she ever settle?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She's mad like a baby gets mad. You forgetting how little it is. She wasn't even two years old when she died. Too little to understand.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: For a baby she throws a powerful spell.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No more powerful than the way I loved her.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: What do you pray for Mama?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh, I don't really pray anymore. I just talk.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh, about time. How some things go. Pass on. Some things just stay.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: What things?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Like, the place I was at before here - Sweet Home. Even if that whole farm and every tree and blade of grass on it died - it'll still be there. Waiting. And if you go and stand in the place where it was, what happened there once, will happen again.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: If it's still there, waiting, that mean nothing ever dies?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Nothing ever does. That's why I had to get my children out. No matter what. That's why you can never go there.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You never tell me all what happened. Just that they whipped you and you run off pregnant with me.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You don't need to know nothing else.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I saw a white dress kneeling next to you when you was praying.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: White? Maybe it was my bedding dress. Describe it to me.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Had a high neck. Whole mess of buttons coming down the back.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Buttons. Well, that's not my bedding dress. I never had a button on nothing. What else?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: A bunch at the back. On the sit down part.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: A bustle?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I don't know what it's called.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You say it was holding on to me. How?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Kneeling next to you while you were praying. I mean, talking. It looked just like you.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well, I'll be.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I think it was a sign. I think maybe baby's got plans.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What plans?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I don't know, but that dress holding onto you got to mean something.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Maybe. Maybe it does.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: She's crawling again.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul? Paul D.? Is that you?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: How you been girl, besides barefoot?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You looking good.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Devil's confusion. He lets me look good long as I feel bad.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: How long has it been?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: 'Bout eighteen years, I figure.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Eighteen years.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: And I swear I been walking every one of them. Mind if I join you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You want to soak them? Let me get you some water.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: No, uh, uh. Can't baby feet. A whole more tramping they got to do yet.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You're not leaving right away, are you? You stay awhile.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well, long enough to see Baby Suggs, you..Where is she?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Dead.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Aw no. When?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Eight years now. Almost nine.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Was it hard? I hope she didn't die hard.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Soft as cream. Being alive was the hard part. Sorry you missed her though. Is that what you came by for?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: That's some of what I came for. The rest is you.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: The truth be known, I go anywhere these days. Anywhere they let me sit down.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Come on inside.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Porch is fine. Cool out here. Sit with me.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: So Baby Suggs is gone. Somehow never thought death would find her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It finds everyone.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: We managed well enough without meeting it.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I suppose.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I wouldn't have to ask about him, would I?...You'd tell me if there was anything to tell, wouldn't you?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You know I would. But I don't know any more about what happened to Halle now than I did then.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You must think he's still alive.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No. I think he's dead. It's just not being sure that keeps him alive.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What did Baby Suggs think?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Same. Ha, listen to her, all her children dead and she felt each one go the very day and hour it happened.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: When she say Halle went?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You had that baby, did you? Damn, never thought you'd make it. Running off pregnant.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Had to. Couldn't be no waiting.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: All by yourself too.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Almost. A white girl helped me.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Then she helped herself, God bless her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: We got spare rooms. You could stay the night, if you had a mind to.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You don't sound too steady in the offer.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh it's..it's truly meant. I just hope you'll pardon my house.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: My house. I like the sound of that.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You got company?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: On and off.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Good God! What kind of evil you got in there?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It's not evil..It's just..just sad. Come on. Just step through.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I thought you said she died soft as cream.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh that's not Baby Suggs. That's my daughter. The one I sent ahead with the boys before I run off.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: She didn't live?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: The boys too?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No, they alive - they run off before Baby Suggs died. The one I was carrying when I left Sweet Home is all I got left.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well, probably best..If a Negro boy got legs he ought to use them. Sit down too long, somebody figure out a way to tie them up.......  You by yourself then?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Me and Denver... my daughter.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: No man?  And that's all right by you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It's all right by me...I cook at a restaurant in town. Sew a little on the sly....

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You look more done in by a walk through my front hall than all those eighteen years of walking put together.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Got that right.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Daddy?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Baby, this here's Paul D. Garner...Paul, this is my Denver...Paul's the last of the Sweet Home men.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Good morning Miss Denver. It's a pleasure.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. D.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Garner, baby. Paul D. Garner.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Glad to get a look at you. Last time I saw your mama, you were pushing out the front of her dress. She's a fine looking young lady, Sethe. Fine looking. Got her daddy's sweet face.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You knew my father?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Knew him. Knew him well.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Of course he did. I told you, he's from Sweet Home. Paul may stay with us a while. Won't that be nice, having an old friend stay a spell?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: If that's all right with you, that is?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: We have a ghost here, you know.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: We met. But sad, your mama said. Not evil.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No sir, not evil. But not sad either.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What then?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Lonely.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't see how it could be lonely spending every minute with us like it does.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: It's my sister. She was just a baby when she died in this house.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Reminds me of that headless bride back behind Sweet Home. Remember that Sethe? Used to roam them woods regular.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Mama doesn't like talk about Sweet Home. Says it was never sweet and it sure wasn't home.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Girl, mind yourself!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Now, now, she got it right there, Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: But it's where we were. All together. It's where I met your father. And it comes back on us whether we want it to or not....

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Then why don't you ever tell me about it?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Denver, start up the stove. Paul must be hungry.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Don't go to no trouble on my account.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Bread's no trouble. The rest I brought back from where I work. Least I can do, cooking dawn to noon, is bring dinner home. You got any objections to pike?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: If he don't object to me I don't object to him.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Where's he going to sleep? Baby Sugg's room got no sheets or nothing.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: We'll figure it out.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Maybe you should stay with mama, Mr. Garner. Then you two can talk about Sweet Home all night long.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What's the matter with you! I never knew you to behave like this!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Leave her be, Sethe. I'm a stranger to her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: That's just it. She got no cause to act up with a stranger.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Baby, what is it? Did something happen?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I can't no more! I can't no more!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Can't what? What can't you?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I can't live here! I don't know where to go or what to do but I can't live here. Nobody speaks to us. Nobody comes by. Nobody even knows I'm alive.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What she talking about 'nobody speaks to you'?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It's the house. People don't...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: It's not! It's not the house! It's us! It's you! SETHE Denver!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Leave off, Sethe. It's hard for a young girl living in a haunted place. That can't be easy.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It's easier than some other things. Come here, baby..

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I'm a grown man with nothing new left to see or do and I'm telling you it' ain't easy. Maybe you oughta move.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No. No moving. No leaving. It's all right the way it is.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You going to tell me it's all right with this child half out of her mind.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I got a tree on my back and a haunt in my house and nothing in between but the daughter I'm holding in my arms. No more running - from nothing! I will never run from another thing on this earth, you hear! I took one journey and I paid the ticket but let me tell you something, Paul D. Garner; it cost too much! Do you hear me?! It cost too much! Now sit down and eat with us or leave us be!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What tree, Sethe?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What tree on your back? I don't see nothing growing on your back.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It's there all the same.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Who told you that?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: White girl. That's what she called it. I never seen it and never will. But she said that's what it looked like. A chokecherry tree. Leaves, branches. That was 18 years ago. Could have cherries by now for all I know...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I don't follow.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I had milk, see. I was pregnant with Denver but I had milk for my baby girl that I sent ahead with the boys. I hadn't stopped nursing her when I sent her and the boys ahead of me. Anybody could smell me long before they saw me. Nothing I could do about it. All I knew is I had to get my milk to my little girl. Nobody was going to nurse her like me. Nobody was going to get it to her fast enough or take it away when she had enough..nobody knew she couldn't pass her air if you held her up on your shoulder, only if she was lying on your knee..Nobody knew that but me...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: We was talking about a tree, Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Schoolteacher's boys drag me into the barn and took my milk...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: The loft?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I told Mrs. Garner on them. She had that lump on her neck and couldn't speak but her eyes rolled out tears, I remember. Them boys found out I told on 'em and Schoolteacher made one open up my back, and when it closed it made a tree.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: They used cowhide on you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: And they took my milk.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: They beat you and you was pregnant?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: And they took my milk!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Aw Lord, girl.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: GOD DAMN IT! HUSH UP! Leave this place alone! Get the hell outta here!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: YOU WANT TO FIGHT, COME ON! GOD DAMN IT! SHE GOT ENOUGH WITHOUT YOU! SHE GOT ENOUGH!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Why don't you...take a rest..I'll call you when we're ready.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sure you don't want me to help clean up?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No..you'd just get in my way. Denver and me'll do it.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: How's this?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Here?! out in the open?!

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Look around - can you see anybody?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Then nothing can see us neither.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: You are a beautiful sight.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't talk stupid.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: You're my wife now! I can talk as stupid as I like about you!  we're gonna have us a liiife..

Speaker: sixo
Dialogue: Freedom mean something anytime it come.

Speaker: neighboring farmer
Dialogue: You spoil these nigger boys.

Speaker: garner
Dialogue: Maybe you got boys on your farm. My nigger's are men. Not a boy among'em. Bought 'em thataway, raised'em thataway.

Speaker: neighboring farmer
Dialogue: Beg to differ Garner. Ain't no nigger men.

Speaker: garner
Dialogue: Not if you scared. But if you a man yourself, you'll want your niggers to be men too.

Speaker: neighboring farmer
Dialogue: Wouldn't have no nigger men around my wife.

Speaker: garner
Dialogue: Neither would I..Neither would I.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'll call you when there's something to eat.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe.  I was thinking of looking for work around here. What do you think?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Ain't much. River mostly. And hogs.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Hogs is fine.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I don't need much, Sethe. Eat, sleep, sing a little when it strikes me. I don't ask for more to..to live somewhere.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: All right. It's...it's fine with me.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Your girl Denver. Seems she's of a different mind.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't worry about her. She's a charmed child. Nothing ever touch her too bad. From the beginning. Everybody I knew dead or gone, but not her.  You got to know something, though - this here ain't no better life. It's just not that other one. What I do here - all I ever do - is keep Denver from that other..So if you stay, there's no more talk about Sweet Home or anything else. I won't let the past in my yard again. Getting me and Denver through this here life is all that matters. You understand?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Dangerous to love anything that much, Sethe. Best thing is to love everything just a little bit..that way, when it breaks or runs off or gets taken, well maybe you'd have a little love left over for the next one.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't be asking me to choose, Paul D. There ain't no choice here.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: That's the whole point. I'm not asking you to choose. Just want to know if there's some space for me. Want to know if it's more than "you can stay", "it's fine"..more like, "I want you here Paul".

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Maybe we should leave things the way they are.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: How are they?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: We get along.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What about inside?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't go inside.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe, if I'm here with you, with Denver, you can go anywhere you want. Jump, if you want to, 'cause I'll catch you. Go as far inside as you need - I'll hold your ankles. Make sure you get back out. I'm not saying this because I need a place to stay. I told you, I'm a walking man, but I been heading in this direction for seven years. When I got here and sat out there on the porch, waiting for you, well, I knew it wasn't the place I was heading toward. It was you. We can make a life girl. A life.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't know. I don't know.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Leave it to me. See how it goes. No promises, if you don't want to make any. Just see how it goes, all right?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: All right. We'll see how it goes.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You willing to leave it to me?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well..some of it.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Some?...Well okay...some.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: What is it? What's wrong?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Nothing. Nothing's wrong. Lay back down.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You think baby ghost's really gone?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't know.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I miss her.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I do. Baby Suggs told me baby ghost would never hurt me. She was my sister. When I was little, after the boys left, I used to think that she and me both were waiting for daddy to come. And once he did, she wouldn't be mad no more.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Wish he'd shut-up...He's ruined everything.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No, he hasn't. He won't.  He..he wants to takes us to the carnival next Thursday...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You mean, go out where they'll be other people?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Dress up a little bit. Wear our hats. What do you think?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Maybe....

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Maybe...All right...all right.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: On what mama? Countin' on what?

Speaker: carnival barker
Dialogue: All Pickaninnies free!!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Two pennies and an insult well spent in my opinion to see the spectacle of whitefolks making a spectacle of themselves.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Mind if I take a sip?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Look. What is that?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You from around here?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Those shoes look brand new.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What might your name be?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Beloved.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Beloved. You use a last name, Beloved?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Last. No..just Beloved..  B..E..L..O..V..E..D...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: That's a pretty name Beloved. Take off your hat and I'll make us something. We just got back from the carnival over near Cincinnati-

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Miss...Miss, you want to lay down?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I'll take her up. She can sleep in baby Suggs room - that all right Mama?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Course.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Look at her feet? They're not walking feet. More like she rode from somewhere all the way here.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sounds like the croup.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Is she feverish, Denver?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No. She's cold.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Then she is. Fever goes from hot to cold.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Could have the cholera.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: She's not sick!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Beloved? Beloved I'm here...what is it?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Heavy..this place is heavy.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Would you like to sit up?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Can I get you anything? Are you hungry?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: ..then you fold it over like this see. This here used to be where my brothers and me slept. I was always at the top.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: How you get so smart?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I ain't so smart.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Yes you are!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Well, I used to go to Lady Jones. She'd teach us with songs how to spell and count.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You don't go no more?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No I...I had to stop going.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You so smart. Tell me about your brothers.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Well..they're names were Howard and..

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: ..and....and Bulgar...At night, we used to..crawl into bed together..I'd lay down on Bul's lap and Howard would tell us die- witch stories. He said they would protect us...And if I learned them, they would protect me if ever they were gone...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You gonna just feed her, from now on?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Denver likes her. She's no real trouble.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: But don't she have a home? Some place to go?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Didn't mention one. I thought we'd wait until her breathing got better. She still sounds a little lumbar.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: She breathe like she can eat, she could blow this whole house down. And all those sweets.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Sometimes the body needs that sugar for strength when it's trying to recover after an illness.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: But that's just it. She don't seem sick. Something funny about her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Funny? How?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Acts sick, sounds sick but she don't look sick. Good skin, bright hands and strong as a bull.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She can hardly walk without holding onto something.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: That's what I mean. Can't walk but I passed by Baby Sugg's room this morning and saw her lifting the rocker with one hand.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You didn't?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Don't tell me. Ask Denver. She was right there.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Denver. Come in here a minute.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul says you saw Beloved pick up the rocking chair in Baby Suggs room with one hand. That so?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I didn't see no such thing.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Have you seen her? I can't find her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Beloved.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She need a marker. Somethin' to tell me where she is. But I ain't got no money.

Speaker: engraver
Dialogue: What you got then?

Speaker: engraver
Dialogue: What you want it to say?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I was thinking what the preacher say at the funeral. Dearly Beloved.

Speaker: engraver
Dialogue: For ten minutes I give you one word for free.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh!...I didn't know you were there.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Can I help?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Help what, honey?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Where you go in the morning?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Work. I work in a restaurant.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: What time you go?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Little after the sun come up. I like to make a loaf of bread before I go. How you feelin'?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You remember your mother at all?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I remember a woman who was mine and I remember bein snatched away from her.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I'm helpin make your bread.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Where your diamonds?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Diamonds? What would I be doing with diamonds?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: On your ears.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Wish I did.  Hmm..come to think of it, I had some crystal once. A present from Mrs. Garner - woman I worked for at Sweet Home.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I never saw you with no earrings.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Gone. Long gone.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Tell me...Tell me about your diamonds...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Ma'am don't talk about Sweet Home.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Tell me...Tell me about your diamonds.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well..this lady I worked for in Kentucky gave them to me when I got married..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: ..What they called married back then. I remember going up to her in the kitchen to tell her. I'd help her make ink for Mr. Garner in the kitchen. I was fool enough to think I was going have some kind of ceremony...maybe even a new dress..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Best unbraid that hair.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Tomorrow.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Today's always here. Tomorrow never.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: It hurts.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Comb it everyday, it won't..

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Your woman never fixed up your hair?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: My woman?..You mean my mother?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: If she did I don't remember. I don't think I saw her but a few times.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Tell me 'bout her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: ..I remember once, she picked me up and carried me behind the smokehouse... The only thing I do remember in fact...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: ...She opened up her dress and right on her rib, right here, was a circle and a cross burnt right into the skin....

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Any more beans?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: ...anyway, she points to this mark and says to me "This is your ma'am. I am the only one whose got this mark now. The rest all dead. If something happens to me and you can't tell me by my face, you can know me by this mark"..Scared me so... I couldn't think of anything to say so I said "Yes Ma'am..but how will you know us? Mark me too. Mark the mark on me too."

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Did she?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No. She slapped my face. I didn't understand it then. Not until I had a mark of my own...

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: What happened to her?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't know. Everybody done?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well, as long as we're all asking questions, getting to know each other..  Why don't you tell us a little bit about yourself?

Speaker: nan
Dialogue: That's your mama - right there.

Speaker: nan
Dialogue: ..I'm telling you, small girl Sethe...Me and your Mama was taken by the men many times..She threw them other babies away..the others from the whites, without names, she threw them away..But you she gave the name of the black man. She had her arms around him, child. The others, she did not put her arms around. Never...Never...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: She has us now!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You been here five weeks, we still don't know nothing bout you..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul, Stop it. Denver bring those dishes.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What was you looking for when you came here?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: This place. I was looking for this place I could be in.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Somebody tell you about this place?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: She told me. When I was at the bridge, she told me.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Must be somebody from the old days.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: How'd you come? Who brought you?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I walked here. A long, long, long, long way. Nobody bring me.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You had new shoes. If you walked so long why don't your shoes show it?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul D. stop picking on her.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I want to know! Where'd you get them shoes and that dress you had on?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I take the shoes!  The shoe strings don't fit! I...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You all right?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I want to go to sleep now.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Come to my room. I can watch out for you up there.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I don't understand what the hold is. It's clear why she holds onto you, but I just can't see why you holding on to her.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What you care who's holding on to who? Feeding her is no trouble. And she's nice company for Denver.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: We was just starting to feel a little like a family ourselves.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Is that what's got your teeth on edge?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I can't place it. It's a feeling in me.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You wanna feel somethin!? ... Feel how it is to have a bed to sleep in and somebody there not worrying you to death about what you got to do each day to deserve it. And if that don't get it, feel how it feels to be a colored woman roaming the roads with anything God made liable to jump on you. Feel that!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I know every bit of that, Sethe. I wasn't born yesterday and I never mistreated a woman in my life!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well, that makes one of you in this world.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: One? Not two.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No. Not two!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What Halle ever do to you? Halle stood by you. He never left you.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Ha, what'd he leave then if not me, huh?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I don't know but it wasn't you. That's a fact.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Then he did worse - he left his children.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You don't know that.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: HE WASN'T THERE! He wasn't where he said he would be! I had to pack my babies off ahead of me, on their own, so I could stay behind to look for him...Underground agent said by Sunday we had to leave.. Sunday came and he wasn't there.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: He couldn't get out of the loft, I expect.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Loft? What loft?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: The one over your head... The one in the barn.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: He saw? He told you he saw?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You told me. The day I came here. You said they stole your milk. I never knew what messed Halle up. That was it, I guess. I seen him the day after you left. Says where you been Halle? All he says to me was "the loft". I asked him what he meant not going with you but he never answers me. But I knew was something broke him. Not one of them years of Saturdays, Sundays and nighttime extra never touched him. But whatever he saw go on in the barn that day broke him like a twig.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: He saw them boys do that to me and let them keep on breathing?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: A man ain't a Goddamn ax, Sethe. Chopping, hacking, busting every Goddamn minute of the day. Things get to him. Things he can't chop down cause they inside him. The last time I saw him, I knew he was broken for good...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What did you say? Didn't you say anything to him?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I couldn't.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Couldn't?! Why the hell not?!

Speaker: white man
Dialogue: Look at Mister there...  You go tell these niggers where to go there Mister! Crow'em right outta here!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I didn't mean to tell you that.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I didn't plan on hearing it.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I can't take it back but I can leave it alone.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Let's do that..let's leave it alone now.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Let it alone. Just sit down and leave it be! Yeah that would be nice. Would be even nicer to lose it altogether - if I had my choice. Halle did. Other people's brains stopped, went crazy. How sweet that would have been. Me and Halle squatting by that churn, smashing cold lumpy butter in our faces, not a care in the world..

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe, don't do this..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What a relief to just stop it all right there, huh?!! Close it shut! Squeeze that butter...But I had three children on their way to Ohio and nothing would have changed that! And you tell me he didn't leave me!!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Guess she's feeling better, huh?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Where'd you learn to dance?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Nowhere. Look at me do this!

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Now you! Come on! Come on!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Why you call yourself Beloved?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: In the dark my name is Beloved.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: What's it like where you were before?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Dark. I'm small in that place. I'm like this here.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Were you cold?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Hot. Nothing to breathe there. No room to move.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: How did you get here?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I wait; then I got on the bridge. I stay there in the dark, in the daytime, in the dark in the daytime. Long time.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: All this time you were on the bridge?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: No. After. When I got out.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Why'd you come here?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: To see her face.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Ma'am's? Sethe's?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Yes. Sethe.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You my sister, ain't you? You really are.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You won't leave us, will you?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: No. Never. This is where I am.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I knew it. I knew. First time I saw you and you said your name. And when you touched me - real gentle. And familiar. Like I'd felt that touch before.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Don't tell mama. You musn't tell her who you really are. I don't know what she'd do! Please, you hear?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Don't tell me what to do? Don't never tell me what to do!?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: But..but I'm on your side. I want to protect you...

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: She's the one! She's the one I need! You can go but she's the one I have to have!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No. Beloved please! Don't go! I didn't do nothing! We were dancing! Don't go!....

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I'm not here to tell you all to clean up your lives and sin no more....I'm not here to tell you we're the blessed meek and are glorybound!...I'm here to tell you that the only grace we can have, is the grace we can imagine...And if you cannot see it, then you shall not have it...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Lay'em down...sword and shield.

Speaker: second boy
Dialogue: YOU GONNA KILL HER! YOU BETTER STOP!

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Look there. A nigger. If that don't beat all...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Man, you 'bout the scariest looking something I ever seen. What you doing back up here?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Running.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Them the feet you running on? My Jesus my...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Am I in Ohio?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Ohio! Fool girl - you in Kentucky. You 'bout a thousand miles from Ohio.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'm still in Kentucky.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You got anything on you, gal, pass for food?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No, ma'am.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: I like to die I'm so hungry. Thought there might be huckleberries. That's why I come up here. You having a baby?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I expect this baby ma'am is gonna die in these wild onions.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Well, I got to eat something.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Where you on your way to, miss?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Boston. Get me some velvet. It's a store called Wilson. I seen pictures and they have the prettiest velvet.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Boston - is that far?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Farther than Ohio.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Must be velvet closer by.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Not like in Boston. Be so pretty on me. You ever touch velvet? Or even seen it?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: If I did, I didn't know it. What's it like?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What they call you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Lu.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What you gonna do, just lay there and foal?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I can't get up.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I can't get up.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: There's a house back yonder. Well, not a house with people in it - more like a lean-to near the river.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: How far?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Make a difference, does it? You stay here, snake might get you.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well, he may come but I can't stand up, let alone walk...and God help me, I can't crawl.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Sure you can Lu..come on..

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Come on Lu! You got to move faster than that. You won't get to Ohio til you ninety years old, you keep moving that ways.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Never know it to look at me but I used to be a good size. Nice arms, everything. That was before they put me in the root cellar...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: ...Mama worked for these people here to pay for her passage but then she had me and died right after so I had to work for'em.. I was fishing off the Beaver once and a nigger floated right by me. I don't like drowned people, do you? Your feet remind me of him. All swole like.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You all bloody back here. Gal you a mess. Undo your dress - let me see.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Lord, I ain't never seen a poorer excuse for a-

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Jesus...It's a tree Lu..A chokecherry tree. I had me some whippings but I don't remember nothing like this. Glad I ain't you.. what God have in mind I wonder. ...You thank your Maker I come along. Spiderwebs all I can do for you. What's in here ain't enough. I'll look outside...Maybe I ought to break them blossoms open and let the pus run..  That you ain't dead yet Lu's a miracle. Make you a bet..You make it through the night, you make it all the way...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: It's gonna hurt now..Anything dead coming back to life hurts. Stop wiggling, girl.  Don't up and die on me in the night, you hear me Lu? I don't want to see your ugly face hankering over me. If you do die, just go on off somewhere where I can't see you, hear?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'll do what I can, miss.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Cause of me, you up and walking. See, Jesus - Lu made it through..I'm good at sick things, ain't I?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yeah, you good...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What's that all over your dress?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Milk..Got to get my milk to my baby girl.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You got another baby waiting for you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I think this one is dead.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You hungry?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I ain't nothing but in a hurry, miss. Got to meet someone...help bring me and my milk to my baby girl...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You want shoes?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Say what?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: I figured how...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Jesus looking at you, girl!

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What you doing that for!? Ain't you got a brain in your head? Stop that right now! I said stop it, Lu. You the dumbest thing on this here earth, LU!..LU!

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, I'm awful sorry 'bout the braggin...I need you here now..Come on Jesus...don't be getting lost on me now.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Damn daddies never around 'cept for the fun part. Biggest joke God made on woman was giving men the planters 'stead of the soil...!! PUSH!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: PULL!!

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: My Lord...She's never gonna know who I am. You gonna tell her? Who brought her into this world. You better tell her, you hear! You say MISS AMY DENVER. Of Boston.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: That's pretty. Denver. Real pretty.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Headin cross?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Anybody know you coming?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yes sir. My mother-in-law over in...

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Take off that coat?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You heard me?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: What am I gonna wear?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You want it back...

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: ..then you go head and take it off this baby. And if you can do that, then go 'way somewhere and don't come back.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Wait here. Somebody be here directly. Don't move. They'll find you.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Thank you. What's your name - so I can remember you right.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Name's Stamp. Stamp Paid. Watch out for that baby, you hear?

Speaker: ellla
Dialogue: Saw the sign a while ago but I couldn't get here no quicker.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What sign?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Stamp always leave the old sty open when there's a crossing. Knots a white rag on the post if it's a child too.  My name's Ella..Where you headed?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: My mother-in-law's. Name's Baby Suggs. She got my other three children I sent ahead.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: When was this one born?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yesterday. I hope she makes it.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Hard to say.  Let's try to get these on your feet.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Oh my Lord...My sweet Lord thank you.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Where's Halle?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: He wasn't there.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Well, he be along presently, I'm sure.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Where are the children?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Not now. You too ugly looking to wake 'em up in the night. First we get you well..

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: You feel this?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Feel what?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Nothing..

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Girl...

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Already crawling - ain't that somethin? ..Come on, baby girl..right this way..Mama's waiting..

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: Pappie come?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Soon.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: All right boys - mama's home now, you be seeing her all the time..Go downstairs and get your supper...Go on...

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Nothing worth saving here.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh wait..Look and see if there's something knotted up in the petticoat. Wedding present. From Mrs. Garner.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Be nice if there was a groom to go with it. What do you think happened to him?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't know. He wasn't where he said to meet him at. I had to get out. I had to. He'll make it. if I made it, Halle sure can.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Well put these on - maybe they'll light his way.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Whatever happens now...God lead you home. So now lay'em down Sethe...Sword and shield..Don't study war no more. Lay all that mess down. Sword and shield...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul? Paul, you home?...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Where else would I be on a Sunday off?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Why don't you come on in here?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul D. What if the girls came in?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I don't hear nobody.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I have to cook.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What you gonna cook?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I thought I'd make some snap beans.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Oh yeah.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Fry up a little corn?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh Paul...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I'm right here baby.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Thank you Lord.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You have brothers or sisters?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: We don't talk about that.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Sethe told us you been walking for eighteen years. Where you been all that time?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Lots of places. I don't remember them all. Don't remember much about anything.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You be surprised what you start remembering once you start talking.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well not me. What's gone is gone. No good come from bringing it back.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul?..Paul?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Mmmm. What?...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I called you two or three times but I gave up round midnight. I thought maybe you went out somewhere.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Damn. I'm sorry honey...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'll make some breakfast - you get yourself washed up.

Speaker: white guard
Dialogue: Hiiiiiii!

Speaker: white guard
Dialogue: Breakfast? Want some breakfast nigger?

Speaker: white guard
Dialogue: Hungry nigger?

Speaker: white guard
Dialogue: Here you go.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What do you want in here?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I want you to touch me on the inside part and call me my name.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: When good people take you in and treat you good, you ought to try to be good back. You don't....Sethe loves you. Much as her own daughter. You know that.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: She don't love me like I love her. I don't love nobody but her.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Then what you come in here for?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I want you to touch me on the inside part.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Ever since you come here - feel like I got a new devil to face.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You have to touch me. On the inside part. And you have to call me my name.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Ain't no chains on me no more. I don't have to do nothing...Now, go back in that house and go to bed.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Call me my name.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: No. Ain't no chains on me...

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Call me.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: ...Ain't no chains on me...

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I'll go if you say it.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Beloved.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Look here Sethe..You ain't gonna like what I got to say but I got to say it...See, it's not the..a man can't...what I mean is, it ain't really me..see, it ain't weakness, the kind of weakness I can fight, that girl is doing it. I know you think I never liked her nohow, still don't, but she is doing it to me anyway. Fixing me, Sethe, she's fixed me and I can't break it...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Man, you make me feel like a young girl, you coming by to pick me up after work. Nobody ever did that before. Better watch out, I might start looking forward to it.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Got to rinse this out.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You get off early or what?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I took off early.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Anything the matter?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: In a way of speaking.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Not cut back?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: No, no. They got plenty of work with them pigs..More they can handle. I just..  You ain't gonna like what I'm about to say, Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well say it, Paul D...whether I like it or not.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I want you pregnant, Sethe. Would you do that for me?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You came by here to ask me that!? You are one crazy-headed man. You right; I don't like it!...Don't you think I'm a little too old to start that all over again?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Think about it.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Mercy.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I been on my feet all day, Paul D.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Where I been? Sitting down!?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Stop! I don't have the legs for this!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Then give'em to me.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You need some babies..somebody to play with in the snow.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I sure would like to give it a try. Need a willing partner though.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'll say..Very, very willing.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Crazy girl. You out here with nothing on.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You got to learn more sense than that.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Evening, girl.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Now I know you not sleeping out there tonight, are you Paul D.?  You come upstairs tonight. Where you belong...and stay there.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: She likes him here...  Make him go away.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: She'd be mad if he leaves.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: OOoo..didn't that hurt you?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: It's like my dreams...I get two dreams, see..One, I exploding...BUUOOGGG...The other I being swallowed. Sometimes it's hard to keep my head on my neck, or these legs connected to my hips...One day I think I might wake up and I'll be in pieces..  Maybe it's starting.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Oh stop. It's just a tooth. Probably wisdom. Does it hurt?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Then why don't you cry?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: If it hurts, why don't you cry?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What you think about Schoolteacher?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: He white, ain't he?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I mean, is he different like Mr. Garner was?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: How was he different?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well, he and Mrs. Garner - they ain't like other whites I seen before. Mr. Garner always spoke soft, for one. Mrs. Garner too.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Don't matter. Loud or soft, what they say is the same.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Mr. Garner let you buy out your mother. Found that house for her to live in from those friends of his in Ohio...

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Yep. He did.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: If he hadn't, she would have dropped in his cooking stove.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Still, he did it. Let you work off her fee, lending yourself out on Sundays. He could of said no. He didn't tell you no.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: No, he didn't tell me no. She worked here ten years. If she worked another ten, ya think she would have made it? I pay him for her last years and in return he got you, me and three more coming..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: He always treated you fair. Called you all men - said he never wanted niggers on his farm.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: That's just it. We was men because he said so. We was men because we was on his land. You think he be calling us men if we ever walked off his land?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: When we walk, don't matter what they call you. You'll be free.

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Sethe..baby girl, that ain't gonna happen. Not by walking, anyway.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What you mean?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Schoolteacher in there told me to quit lending myself out.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: But..then..how you gonna buy yourself out? Or them?  Or me?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Ain't gonna be no buying us out, like I did with mama. Or them. As far as Schoolteacher concerned, ain't no other life ahead for any of us but this one.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Halle....what we going to do?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Sixo, ya know he creeps out at night..he says the way they took my ma'am..he says freedom is that way. He and Paul A. got a plan.  They heard of this man, what they call an underground agent...if we do what he says, don't need no buy out.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You mean...? But what if we caught? What'd they do to us? To the children?

Speaker: halle
Dialogue: Same thing they're doing now, honey - only quicker.

Speaker: schoolteacher
Dialogue: Which one are you doing?

Speaker: schoolteacher
Dialogue: No, no. That's not the way. I told you to put her human characteristics on the left; her animal ones on the right. And don't forget to line them up.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Want me to loosen it up with a little water?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yes ma'am...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yes Ma'am. Look like it.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: They don't need telling.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Yes ma'am.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Hurry up. You're late.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Here!

Speaker: howard
Dialogue: But ma'am...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Just go with her! Do what I tell ya!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Put sugar water on that cloth for her to suck so she won't forget me til I come.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Where you going?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Halle wasn't there. I gotta go back.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You crazy..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Take em out. Now! I'll get there myself. I got her milk...I'll get there...Don't worry.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Go..Go! Now!

Speaker: bulgar
Dialogue: Mama?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Ain't just a job reason to sing. Other things a man's got to look forward to that a job just a way to spend your day til the good times arrive.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Now, now...it's all a state a mind, right Paul D. If you can think it, it can happen.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: More than that. When a man can make plans then a man can make good times happen.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Better then gold, my friend. Me and my woman's planning on starting a family.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: New life. Born free, hear! Now if that don't define a good tine, I don't know what does.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What you talkin? Nobody owns us no more. Nobody gonna own my children neither.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: May I?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Free country. No matter what anybody says.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I like the way you think, boy. Good. Good to think that way. Friend of mine, Baby Suggs was her name...sort of became a preacher in these parts..that was her way of thinking too. When she was at her best, that is.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You knew Baby Suggs?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Oh yes...You're not one of her Sweet Home men, now are you?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Yes sir...Me and my brothers and her son.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Oh, I see now.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe told me she died soft as cream.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Well...maybe on the outside.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Why is that?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You don't know, son, do you? See I had to figure that out first.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Know what?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: That there's a picture of Sethe.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe?  Nah, that ain't her mouth. I can see where you might think it around the eyes but that there ain't her mouth. Besides, why would some black woman's picture be in the paper?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You don't read son, do you?  You want me to read to you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Already fed the girls. You eat?  Want something?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Best you come inside.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I don't have to tell you about Sweet Home. What it was. But maybe you don't know what it was like for me to get away from there.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I did it. I got us all out. Without Halle too. Up til then it was the only thing I ever did on my own. Decided. And it came off right like it was supposed to..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: We was here. Each and every one of my babies and me too. I birthed them and I got 'em out and it wasn't no accident. I did that! I had help, of course, lots of that, but still it was me doing it; me saying, "Go on" and "Now!". Me having to look out. Me using my own head. But it was more than that. It was a kind of ...'thinking-about-myself' I never knew nothing about before. It felt good. Good and right. I was big, Paul, and deep and wide and when I stretched out my arms all my children could get in between. I was that wide. Look like I loved them more after I got them here. Or maybe I couldn't love'em proper in Sweet Home 'cause they wasn't mine to love. But when I got here, when I jumped off that wagon - there wasn't nobody in the world I couldn't love if I wanted to....

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Let the children come!

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Let your mother's hear you laugh!!

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Let the grown men come!!

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: LET YOUR WIVES AND YOUR CHILDREN SEE YOU DANCE!

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Now...you women...I want you to cry. For the living. For the dead....Just cry.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: ....Something in me knew Halle was never gonna knock on our door. He was never gonna see what I saw that day. I saw what men look like...and I saw mothers, for the first time.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: What a sight you are, Stamp.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Worth it though. Just one bite of these berries and you feel down right anointed.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She's too little for that, Stamp. Her bowels be soup.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: It'll sickify her stomach..Now go wash up round back...crazy fool..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It was real nice of him.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: He's a good one, no doubt of that. I can get three, maybe four pies out of this. Seems a shame just for us though. I'm gonna invite Ella and John over...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: How 'bout if I make a couple of chickens to back it up?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Howard!...Bulgar!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: The shed!...Get in the shed!...Run!

Speaker: nephew
Dialogue: What she go and do that for?...What she go and do that for?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You all better go on.  Nothing here to claim, I guess. Look like your business is over. Mine's started.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I'll have to take you in. No trouble now. You've done enough to last you....

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You come quiet, here, and I won't have to tie you up.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Sethe. You take my arm and gimme yours.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I'm going out here and send for a wagon.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I beg you pardon..I beg your pardon..

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Excuse me..but the child needs nursin..needs the mother's milk..

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Then she's best come too.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: One at a time!...And you gotta clean yourself up!

Speaker: white boy
Dialogue: Mama says Wednesday. She says you got to have them fixed by Wednesday.

Speaker: white boy
Dialogue: You hear, Baby? She says Wednesday.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I beg your pardon..Lord, I beg your pardon..I sure do....

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Your love is too thick, Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Love is or it isn't. Thin love ain't love at all...I did stop him. I took and put my babies where they'd be safe...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Didn't work though, did it?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It worked.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: How? Your boys gone, you don't know where. One girl dead, the other can't go farther than the yard. How did it work?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: They ain't at Sweet Home! Schoolteacher ain't got'em!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Maybe there's worse.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: It ain't my job to know what's worse. It's my job to know what is and keep them away from what I know is terrible. I did that.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What you did was wrong, Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I should have gone back there? Taken my babies back there?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: There could have been a way. Some other way.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: What way?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You got two feet, Sethe. Not four!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You can set aside supper for me... Might be late getting back...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: After all I told you, Paul D. and after telling me how many feet I have, you think saying goodbye is gonna break me into pieces?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You're a sweet man.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: So long, Paul D.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: What do these do?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: My Lord...where'd you dig up those?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: There for skating on the ice. We have another pair and half of another, I think.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Can we try them?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Go ice skating? Ha...  Why not?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You sure mama?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Strikes me that after your man leaves, it might just be the wrong time to be scrubbing floors... might just be the perfect time to go ice skating.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Go get the shawls..and find me an old shoe for that half a pair...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Come on, ma'am...try!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I made that song up. I made it up and sang it to my children...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: ...Nobody knows that song but me and my children.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I know it.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Back stiff?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: OOh, yeah...Don't know if it's the floor or the skating.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Could be that fall you took.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: That was fun.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Should I wake her?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No, let her rest.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: She likes to see you off in the morning.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'll make sure she does. But first I'm going  make up a nice, big breakfast against that cold outside.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Won't you be late for work?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't matter. First time I'll be late in nine years. No great trouble..Whatever goes on out there goes on with or without me showing up on time... don't matter...  The world is in this room, baby. This is all there is and all there needs to be.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You missed the Clearing meeting three Saturdays running.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Folks came.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Folks come. Folks go.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Here, let me carry that.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I got a delivery around here. Name of Tucker.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Yonder. Twin chestnuts in the yard.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Well what?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: This Saturday - you coming to Call or what?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: If I call them, and they come what on earth am I going to say to them.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Say the Word!

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: The Word. What you was put here to speak.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: That's the last thing they took from me.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: But you got to do it. You got to. Can't nobody Call like you. You have to be there.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: What I have to do is get in my bed and lay down. I want to fix on something harmless in this world.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: What world are you talking about? Ain't nothing harmless down here.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Blue. That doesn't hurt nobody. Yellow neither.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You getting into bed to think about yellow?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I likes yellow.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Then what? When you get through with blue and yellow, then what?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Can't say. It's something can't be planned.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You blaming God. That what you're doing?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: No, Stamp. I ain't.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You saying whitefolks won. That what you saying?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Those white things have taken all I had or dreamed. I'm saying ain't no bad luck in this world 'cept for white folks..They just don't know when to stop.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You saying nothing counts?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I'm saying they came into my yard.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You saying God give up? Nothing left for us but pour out our own blood?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: I'm saying they came into my yard.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You punishing Him, ain't you?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Not like He punished me.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You can't do that, Baby. It ain't right.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Was a time I knew what was.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You still know.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: What I know is what I see: a nigger woman hauling shoes.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Aw, Baby.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: We have to be steady. "These things too will pass". What you looking for? A miracle?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: No. I'm looking for what I was put here to look for: the back door.

Speaker: sawyer
Dialogue: What the hell you thinking, girl? Strolling in here this late?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't talk to me, Mr. Sawyer. Don't say nothing to me this morning.

Speaker: sawyer
Dialogue: What? What? You talking back to me?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'm telling you don't say nothing to me.

Speaker: sawyer
Dialogue: You better get them pies made!

Speaker: sawyer
Dialogue: Not too sweet! You make it too sweet they don't eat it.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Make it the way I always do.

Speaker: sawyer
Dialogue: Yeah. Too sweet.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Where you been keeping yourself? I told John must be cold if Stamp stay inside.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Oh I been out.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Out where?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Was over to Baby Suggs.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: What you want there? Somebody invite you in?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: That's Baby's kin. I don't need no invite to look after her people.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Somebody new there. A woman. Thought you might know who she is.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Ain't no new Negroes in this town I don't know about. What she look like? You sure that wasn't Denver?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I know Denver.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: You sure?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I know what I see.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Better ask Paul D.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Can't locate him.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: He's sleeping in the church.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: The church!

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Yeah. Asked Rev. Pike if he could stay in the cellar.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: It's cold as charity in there! What he do that for? Any number'll take him in.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Can't nobody read minds long distance. All he have to do is ask somebody.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Why? Why he have to ask? Can't nobody offer? What's going on? Since when a black man come to town have to sleep in the cellar like a dog?!

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Unrile yourself, Stamp. It's only a few days he been there.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: NO! Shouldn't be no days! You know all about it and don't give him a hand? That don't sound like you, Ella. Me and you been pulling colored folk out the water more'n twenty years! Now you tell me you can't offer a man a bed?! A working man who can pay his own way?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: He ask, I give him anything.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Why's that necessary all of a sudden?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: I don't know him that well.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You know he's colored? What else there to know?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Stamp, don't tear me up this morning! I don't feel like it.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: It's her, ain't it?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Her who?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Sethe. He took up with her and stayed in there and you don't want nothing to-

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Hold on! Don't jump if you can't see bottom!

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Girl, give it up! We been friends too long to act like this.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Well, who can tell what went on in there? I never even knew who Sethe was or none of her people.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You know she married Baby Suggs' boy.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: I ain't sure I know that. Baby never laid eyes on her till she showed up here. And how'd she make it and her husband didn't? And where is he? And how she have that baby in the woods by herself? Said a whitewoman help her. Shoot. You believe that? Well, I know what kind of white that was.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Aw, no, Ella.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Anything white floating around in the woods - if it don't got a shotgun, it's something the Lord tells me I don't want no part of.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You was friends.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Till she showed herself.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Ella.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: I ain't got no friends take a handsaw to their own children.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: What's any of that got to do with Paul D.?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: What run him off? Tell me that!

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I run him off.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: You?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I told him...Showed him the newspaper. About Sethe. Read it to him. He left that very day.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: You didn't tell me that. I thought he already knew.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: He didn't know nothing. And nobody. Except her, from when they was at that place Baby Suggs was at.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: He knew Baby Suggs?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Sure he knew her. Her boy Halle, too.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: And he left when he found out what Sethe did?  What you say casts a different light on it, I guess...I thought-

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: But you didn't come here talking 'bout Paul. You came asking about a new girl.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: That's so.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Well, Paul D. must know who she is. Or what she is.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You mind loaded with spirits. Everywhere you look you see one.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: You know as well as I do, Stamp, that people who die bad don't stay in the ground.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Howdy.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You got any more newspaper in that pocket for me, just a waste of time. Ain't interested.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: This is hard for me. But I got to do it. Two things I got to say to you. I'm a take the easy one first.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I come looking for you to ask your pardon. Apologize.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You pick any house, any house where colored live. Pick any one and you welcome to stay there. I'm apologizing 'cause they didn't offer to tell you. But you welcome anywhere you want to be. My house. John and Ella. Miss Lady Jones..anybody. You choose. You ain't got to sleep in no cellar and I apologize for each and every night.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well I...I did get offered one place but I just wanted to be off by myself a spell.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Oh yeah. Oh that's load off. I thought everybody gone crazy.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Just me.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You planning to do anything about it?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Oh yeah. I got big plans.

Speaker: white man
Dialogue: Hey!!

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: white man
Dialogue: I'm looking for a gal name of Judy. Works over by the slaughterhouse. Said she lived on Plank Road.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Plank Road. Yes sir. That's up a ways. Mile, maybe.

Speaker: white man
Dialogue: You don't know her? Judy? Works in the slaughterhouse.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: No sir, I don't, but I know Plank Road. 'Bout a mile up thataway.

Speaker: white man
Dialogue: Look here..There's a cross up there, so I guess this here's a church or used to be. Seems to me like you ought to show it some respect, you follow me?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Yes sir..You right about that. That's just what I come over to talk to him about. Just that..

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You remember your price, Stamp?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Never found out.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I did. Down to the cent.$900. Always wondered though what Mrs. Garner got for my brother Paul F. Must of been more than nine hundred dollars cause she use that money for Sweet Home for almost two years. But then they hung my other brother Paul A. up on a tree so I guess he wasn't worth the same..I wonder what was Baby Suggs worth? And Halle? I wasn't surprised when I found out they tracked down Sethe all the way to Cincinatti. Her price must have been higher than all of us - her being property that reproduced itself without cost. A breeder.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: No use thinking these things now.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Oh but we got to. How we gonna know our price in the future? How are children's children's children gonna know what they cost? Who's gonna tell them? What are they gonna pay for us, if we free?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Children ain't gonna need to know that kind of thing.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: They'll know. They'll know as soon as they born. Cause it's inside us,Stamp. It'll be inside them. We'll pass it down. Schoolteacher didn't just change the outside, he changed the mind..and the blood..and what it carries...and what it's worth..

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I don't believe that. I won't.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: There was a rooster named Mister down at Sweet Home. Last time I saw Halle, with that butter all over his face and me with an iron bit in my mouth, I saw Mister - sitting on a tub. He loved that tub. Like king on a throne. He was a hateful thing. Bloody and evil..But he was better than me.  Mister was allowed to be and stay what he was. Even if you cooked him you'd be cooking a rooster named Mister. But wasn't no way I'd ever be Paul D. again..Schoolteacher changed me. Was never no beating under Mr. Garner. Schoolteacher changed that. Why wouldn't a man run from that? Why wouldn't a man not work, kill, starve, pull out his own heart to stop feeling 'stead of feeling that? And it strikes me, it's got to be cause we were something else. And that something was less than a chicken sitting in the sun on a tub.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I said I had two things to say to you. I only told you one. I have to tell you the other.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I don't want to know.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: I was there Paul D...There in the yard. When she did it.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What yard? When who-

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Jesus.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: It ain't what you think.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You don't know what I think.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: She ain't crazy. She love those children. She was trying to outhurt the hurter's all.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Leave off..

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: She was only-

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Stamp, leave off I said! I knew her when she was a girl. She scares me and I knew her when she was a girl...

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: You ain't scared of Sethe. I don't believe you.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: She scares me. I scare me. And that girl in her house scares me.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: Who is she? Where she come from?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Don't know. Just shot up one day from a stump.

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: She what run you off? Not what I told you 'bout Sethe?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Tell me something, Stamp. Tell me this one thing. How much is a nigger supposed to take?

Speaker: stamp paid
Dialogue: All he can. All he can.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Why? Why? Why? Why? Why?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You shouldn't be in here?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: What do you know about it? I sleep where I want.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: You best leave that quilt alone. That was grandma's quilt.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: Breakfast ready? I'm hungry!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Morning, ma'am.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You hungry?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No, ma'am.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I'll finish those. Why don't you sit down?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You don't sit with me!!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Baby, don't be like that.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You don't sit with me!! I don't sit with people who leave me!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't talk like that. Your mama loves you.

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I had another dream last night.  The dead man laying on top of me and I had nothing to eat. And the ghosts without skin stuck their fingers in me and said Beloved in the dark and bitch in the light..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Don't say those things. You forget about those dreams..

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You gave me the bad dreams. You left me behind...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Mama told you - I'd give up my own life, every minute, every hour of it to take back one of your tears baby...My children my best thing. You my best thing!

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: You're weren't nice to me..you didn't smile at me..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: That's not true. I told you, I had to get you out, make you safe...so's you and me could be together on the other side, forever..

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Ma'am...

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: LIAR!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: MAMA!

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Hold back Denver - I'm fine..You..you go on upstairs. I'll do the cleaning up.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: But mama..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Go upstairs I said!!

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: You mean I never told you about your daddy? About the Bodwins who let me rent this here house while I do my shoe repairing? About your mother's feet, not to mention her back? I never told you all that?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Is that why you can't walk down the steps and out yonder by yourself?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Why you never go back to Lady Jone's and learn your letters? You liked going there I remember. Seeing the other children. Then all a sudden, you stop.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: There was a boy there...said mama was a jailbird...said he could prove it..

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: My Jesus my...What people won't say. Why didn't you come and ask me?  Come here, child..

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: You got to go sometime. You got to go out there by yourself sometime.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: But you said...you said out there, there ain't no...what was that word?..no..de- fense. No de-fense.

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: There ain't.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Then what do I do?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: Know it, and go on out the yard. Go on.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Mama?

Speaker: beloved
Dialogue: I look just like her.

Speaker: denver
