Dialogue: Mama let me help you.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: NO!...She wanted me to do it.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: Why Denver..Look at you.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: It's been so long. It's so nice of you to come see me. What brings you?

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: Well, never mind - nobody needs a reason to visit. Let me make us some tea. Come on.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: How's your family, honey?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I want to work, Miss Lady.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: Work? Start learnin your letters again?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No. I mean work work.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: Well, what can you do?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I can't do anything but I would learn it for you if you have a little extra.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: Extra?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Food. My mama, she doesn't feel well. I couldn't stay away from her too long, cause of her condition but I could do chores in the mornings.

Speaker: lady jones
Dialogue: Oh baby...I don't know anyone could pay anybody anything for work they did themselves...But if you all need to eat until your mother's well, all you have to do is say so...We have a church committee invented so nobody had to go hungry.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No..No that won't do...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: BABY!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: No, darling. That's not my bowl. Mine's got a blue ring around it..Would you like to come in a spell?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Nobody..no sir..that's right..nobody's going be doing that..nobody going be writing my daughter's characteristics on the animal side..no sir..I don't care..ain't laying that down..no sir. I refuse..that's right..that's right...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Mama...Mama she's asleep. Why don't you eat something.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She likes this dress...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: But you'll hurt your eyes doin it there. Come sit at the table.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Please mama, eat something...

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: May I come in?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: What you want?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I want to see Mr. and Mrs. Bodwin.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: Miss Bodwin. They brother and sister, darlin.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: What you want'em for?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I'm looking for work. I was thinking they might know of some.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: You Baby Sugg's kin, ain't you?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Yes ma'am.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: I heard your mother took sick, that so?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Yes ma'am..

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: Well, come on in. You letting in flies.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: You know what? I've been here since I was fourteen and I remember like yesterday when Baby Suggs, holy, came here and sat right where you are. Whiteman name of Garner brought her. He and Mr. Bodwin were good friends. That's how she got that house you all live in. Other things too.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Yes ma'am.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: I never went to those woodland services but she was always nice to me. Always. Never be another like her.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I miss her.

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: Bet you do. Everybody miss her. That was a good woman...Well, I don't know whether the Bodwins think it or not but they sure could use some extra help.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Ya think?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: They getting older now and I can't take care of 'em like I used to. More and more they keep asking me to sleep over night. Now, I don't want to quit these people but they can't have all my days and nights too. I got my own family needs me. It'll take some convincing but maybe you could come after supper - take care of your mama during the day, then earn a little something at night, how's that?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Fine. But what would I do at night?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: Be here. In case.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: In case of what?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: In case the house burn down or bad weather slops the roads so bad I can't get here on time or late guests needed cleaning up after. Anything.  Don't ask me what whitefolks need at night.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: They good whitefolks?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: Oh yeah. They good. Can't say they ain't good. I wouldn't trade them for another pair, tell you that. But you come back in a few days - give me a chance to lead'em to it. All right?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: What is it, child? What's the trouble with Sethe?

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: But is it really the daughter, Janey? The killed one?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: That what she say.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: It's sitting there. Sleeps, eats and raises hell. Whipping Sethe every day.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: I'll be. A baby?

Speaker: janey
Dialogue: No. Grown now. The age it would have been had it lived.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: In the flesh. And whipping her.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Nobody got that coming.

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: No, and the children can't just up and kill the mama. What's fair ain't necessarily right...  Now you all know how I felt about the whole thing. I know the rage Sethe felt in that shed that day.  We all do. But what I could not understand, and still don't, was her reaction to it. Prideful. Too damn complicated for a black woman in her position before God. But whatever she done, I don't like the idea of past errors taking possession of the present. I don't cotton to sin moving in on a house, unleashed and sassy. Every day life takes enough, takes all a woman has. "Sufficient unto the day is evil thereof" and nobody needs more. Nobody needs a grown up evil sitting at a table with a grudge. As long as that ghost showed itself from a ghostly place, I respected it. But once it take on flesh and come into this world, well, the shoe's on the other foot now. I don't mind a little communication between worlds. But this here's an invasion.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: Should we pray?

Speaker: ella
Dialogue: Uh-huh. First. Then we got to get down to business.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Mama?....Mama I'm going out..  Mama, I got a job. Working over at the Bodwins at night. Mr. Bodwin coming over now to pick me up on his way back from town. I'll be staying there nights and coming back here for the daytime. We'll have some money, mama..Mama?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I'm going help you, mama. Don't you give up yet.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No...No, he's not coming into my yard. He not taking my best thing...No..

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No...no...no..

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Mama?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No...NO..NO..NOOOOOOOOOOOO!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: MAMA...NOOOOOOO!

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Good morning, Paul D.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well, is it now? How you getting along?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Don't pay to complain.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You on your way home?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No. Got me an afternoon job at the shirt factory. Figure between that and my night work at the Bodwins I might be able to put something away for me and mama.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: They treating you right over at the Bodwins?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: More than all right. Miss Bodwin, she teach me stuff..Book stuff. She says I might go to Oberlin. She's experimenting on me.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Your mother all right?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: No. Not a bit all right. Hasn't gotten out of bed since that day.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You think I should stop by? Think she'd welcome it?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I don't know. I think I've lost my mother, Paul D.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: That girl...You know, Beloved...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: She gone like they say?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Haven't seen her since that day. Ella thinks she might be waiting in the woods for another chance but..I don't think so. Mama thinks she's gone for good. Says she can feel it.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You think she sure 'nough your sister?

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: At times. At other times I think she was...more. But who would know that better than you. I mean, you sure 'nough you her.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well, if you want my opinion...

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: I don't. I have my own.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You grown.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Yes sir

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Well, good luck with the job.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: denver
Dialogue: And Paul D...you don't have to stay 'way, but be careful how you talk to my mama, hear?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: Hey, Miss Denver..Wait up!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Sethe?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Paul D.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Aw, Sethe.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: You shaved.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Yeah. Look bad?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: No, You looking good.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Devil's confusion. What's this I hear about you not getting out of bed?  I saw Denver. She tell you?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She comes in the daytime.  She still with me, my Denver.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You got to get up from here, girl.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: I'm tired, Paul. So tired. I have to rest a while.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Don't you die on me!! This is Baby Suggs quilt. Is that what you planning!?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Oh, I don't have no plans. No plans at all.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Look - Denver be here in the day. I be here in the night. I'm a take care of you, you hear? Starting now.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What, baby?

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She left me. She's gone again.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Aw, girl. Don't cry...Me and you, we got more yesterday than anybody. We need some kind of tomorrow...

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: She was my best thing.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You your best thing, Sethe. You are.

Speaker: sethe
Dialogue: Me?...Me?

Speaker: baby suggs
Dialogue: ..The only grace we can have, is the grace we can imagine. If you cannot see it, you will not have it...Here, in this place, we are flesh. Flesh that weeps, laughs, dances on bare feet in the grass. Love it. Love it hard. Yonder they do not love your flesh. They despise it. They flay it. O, my people, they do not love your hands. Those they only use, tie, bind, chop off and leave empty, Love your hands. Love them. Raise them up and kiss them. Touch others with them, put them together, stroke them on your face 'cause they don't love that either. You  got to love it. You. Yonder out there, they ain't in love with your moth. They will see it broken and break it again. What you say out of it, they will not heed. What you scream from it they do not hear. No, they don't love your mother. You got to love it. And the feet that need to rest and to dance. The backs that needs support. The shoulders that need arms, strong arms I'm telling you! O my people, out yonder they don't love your neck unnoosed and straight. So love your neck; put a hand on it, grace it, stroke it and hold it up. Love all your inside parts, love 'em..and the beating heart, love that too. More than eyes or feet. More than lungs that have yet to draw free air, love your heart. For this is the prize.
